results.abstract: Scientists and workers at Kennedy Space Center discuss final two space shuttle missions before fleet is retired; say that it will be emotional goodbye after 25 years; Discovery has launch planned for this fall and Endeavour has final mission planned for early winter; photo (M)

headline.main: Approaching Space Center, and End of Line for Shuttle Program

results.snippet: With a train’s delivery of solid-fuel booster segments to Florida, the program has just two trips left.
results.lead_paragraph: NEAR KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. -- A train pulling the last set of space shuttle solid-fuel booster segments reached the Kennedy Space Center last Thursday -- a day after the shuttle Atlantis completed its final planned mission -- in a reminder that the program is nearing the end of the line. ''I remember when we heard about the last solid rocket booster test firing, the last main engine test firing, the last tank manufacturing and now the last set of boosters coming to K.S.C.,'' said the shuttle's launch director, Michael D. Leinbach. ''Yeah, this has been 25 years of my life. It's very, very touching, a lot of emotions kick in.''

headline.main: To Take Baby Pictures of the Universe, Click Here

results.snippet: A telescope will be sent a million miles from Earth to collect images that have been traveling since nearly the beginning of the universe.
results.lead_paragraph: Here was a model for the next great time machine, just over John Grunsfeld's shoulder in a field in Battery Park: a giant telescope that will be launched in 2014 and sent one million miles from Earth. By looking deep into space, it will collect light and images that have been traveling since nearly the beginning of the universe, and send them back here. Dr. Grunsfeld, trim and compact at 51, has floated in space for hours at a time, miles above the Earth, fixing the Hubble Space Telescope.

results.abstract: Russian preparations for travel to Mars revolve around experiments in a hanger in Moscow, where teams of researchers have been spending increasingly long periods locked inside a simulated spacecraft.
results.snippet: Russian preparations for travel to Mars revolve around experiments in a hanger in Moscow, where teams of researchers have been spending increasingly long periods locked inside a simulated spacecraft.
results.lead_paragraph: As The Lede explained last year, Russian preparations for travel to Mars revolve around experiments in a hanger in Moscow, where teams of researchers have been spending increasingly long periods locked inside a simulated spacecraft.

results.snippet: A selected guide to events for and/or by children in and around New York.
results.lead_paragraph: 'TIGERS THE EXHIBITION' The most common way of getting inside a tiger isn't much fun -- just ask the deer in Asia. But now children in New York can inhabit a Bengal tiger through means that are risk free and entertaining, allowing them not only to see the creature's bones and muscles but also to perceive the world through its senses.

results.abstract: Xia Lin, top official at China news agency Xinhua, in lecture to group of journalism students, provides rare insight into how news is stage-managed for mass consumption; photo (M)

headline.main: Leaked Lecture Offers View of China's Efforts to Manage the News

results.snippet: The top official at China’s official news agency told of how the agency gave leaders a fast and accurate picture of events and then changed that picture for the public.

byline.original: By ANDREW JACOBS; Li Bibo and Zhang Jing contributed research

results.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- As the nation held its collective breath, China's first astronaut, Yang Liwei, floated back to the motherland, having orbited Earth 14 times in the Shenzhou 5, or Divine Capsule. It was October 2003, and the national broadcaster CCTV carried live coverage of the momentous event, from Mr. Yang's famous pleasantries uttered in space -- ''I feel good'' -- to the instant that workers opened the capsule door to reveal the pale but smiling face of a hero, offering irrefutable evidence that China's maiden manned space voyage had gone off without a hitch.

results.snippet: The About New York column on Wednesday  about the display at Battery Park of a model of a new space telescope misstated the age of John Grunsfeld, a former astronaut. He is 51, not 52. The article also misstated the amount of time it takes light from...
results.lead_paragraph: The About New York column on Wednesday about the display at Battery Park of a model of a new space telescope misstated the age of John Grunsfeld, a former astronaut. He is 51, not 52. The article also misstated the amount of time it takes light from the moon to reach Earth. It is less than two seconds, not four seconds.

results.abstract: Bigelow Aerospace plans to launch first of two commercially run Sundancer space stations in next four years; second larger station is planned for 2016; design is launched unoccupied and expands with inflatable housing; company will have to buy rides on other commercially produced rockets to ferry passengers back and forth from Earth to space; transportation and stay on station is priced at $25 million per person for 30 days; photos; drawings (M)

headline.main: In New Space Race, Enter the Entrepreneurs

results.snippet: A Nevada company is preparing the solar system’s first private space station.
results.lead_paragraph: NORTH LAS VEGAS, Nev. -- At the Bigelow Aerospace factory here, the full-size space station mockups sitting on the warehouse floor look somewhat like puffy white watermelons. The interiors offer a hint of what spacious living in space might look like. ''Every astronaut we have come in here just says, 'Wow,' '' said Robert T. Bigelow, the company founder. ''They can't believe the size of this thing.''

results.abstract: A Nevada company is preparing the solar system's first private space station.

results.snippet: A selected guide to events for and by children in New York and the area.
results.lead_paragraph: CENTENNIAL BEE-DAY PARTY In Kafka's ''Metamorphosis'' Gregor Samsa awakens to discover that he has become an enormous cockroach. While that may be among the most unwelcome transformations on record, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden will offer one on Saturday that's shorter, sweeter and sunnier: children changing themselves into bees.

results.abstract: Singularity movement sees merger of technology and mind forming superior intelligence which will dominate and take on altered form that cannot be predicted or comprehended in humankind's current, limited state; some of Silicon Valley's smartest and wealthiest people have embraced Singularity movement, possibly several decades away, as possibly only way to solve world's ills and allow people to seize control of evolutionary process; drawing; photo (L)
results.snippet: The Singularity movement sees a time when human beings and machines will merge and overcome illness and perhaps death.
results.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. ON a Tuesday evening this spring, Sergey Brin, the co-founder of Google, became part man and part machine. About 40 people, all gathered here at a NASA campus for a nine-day, $15,000 course at Singularity University, saw it happen.

results.snippet: 9 P.M. (13) LA DANSE: LE BALLET DE L'OPÉRA DE PARIS  In this ''Great Performances'' presentation,  the director Frederick Wiseman observes the dancers of the Paris Opera Ballet -- among them Aurélie Dupont, Laetitia Pujol, Nicolas Le Riche,...
results.lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) LA DANSE: LE BALLET DE L'OPÉRA DE PARIS In this ''Great Performances'' presentation, the director Frederick Wiseman observes the dancers of the Paris Opera Ballet -- among them Aurélie Dupont, Laetitia Pujol, Nicolas Le Riche, Marie-Agnès Gillot and Agnès Letestu -- as they perform seven works: ''Genus'' by Wayne McGregor, ''Paquita'' by Pierre Lacotte, Rudolf Nureyev's ''Nutcracker,'' ''Medea'' by Angelin Preljocaj, ''The House of Bernarda Alba'' by Mats Ek, Sasha Waltz's ''Romeo and Juliet'' and ''Orpheus and Eurydice'' by Pina Bausch. This documentary also offers glimpses of daily classes and rehearsals and ventures behind the scenes at the elegant Palais Garnier, with its scarlet velvet seats and Marc Chagall ceiling, to watch choreographers, ballet masters, musicians and production designers at work. ''To say that the film, sumptuous in its length and graceful in its rhythm, is a feast for ballet lovers is to state the obvious and also to sell Mr. Wiseman's achievement a bit short,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''Yes, this is one of the finest dance films ever made, but there's more to it than that.'' 8 P.M. (CBS) TV's GREATEST SURPRISES: A PALEY CENTER FOR MEDIA SPECIAL Jeff Probst counts down 30 moments that shook viewers to the core, from Bobby Ewing's shower scene in ''Dallas'' to Dr. George O'Malley's death on ''Grey's Anatomy.'' Tina Fey, Ellen DeGeneres, Howie Mandel, Whoopi Goldberg, Paul Shaffer, Regis Philbin, Patricia Heaton and David E. Kelley reveal their own favorite shocks.

results.snippet: A selected guide to events for and by children in New York and the area.
results.lead_paragraph: For Children 'Amazon Voyage: Vicious Fishes & Other Riches' (Friday through Thursday) The anaconda isn't real, but the piranhas are. In this simulated trip down the Amazon, a new exhibition at the New York Hall of Science, children can learn about the creatures of the river, their adaptations and their life cycles. The exhibits include live stingrays, tetra fish and piranhas, and a chance to reach into the belly of a fake piraiba (the Amazon's largest catfish) to see what it eats. (Through Aug. 22.) Friday, 9:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturday and Sunday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Monday through Thursday, 9:30 a.m. to 2 p.m.; New York Hall of Science, 47-01 111th Street, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Queens , (718) 699-0005, nysci.org; free with admission: $11; $8 for college students, 62+ and ages 2 through 17; free for under 2.20100617

results.abstract: Media Decoder blog notes BrosIcingBros.com, Web site closely associated with popular drinking game that involves chugging warm bottles of Smirnoff Ice malt beverage, shuts down; Diageo, parent of Smirnoff, hints at 'measures' taken to defend their brand; photo (M)

results.snippet: A selected guide to events by and for children in the New York area.
results.lead_paragraph: 'DANCING IN THE SKY' Forget about all the world's being a stage -- some parts are much more theatrical than others. And few outdoor spaces in New York appear more suited to everyday human dramas than the High Line, the elevated railway-turned-park on the West Side of Manhattan.

results.abstract: Crown Archetype will release "Jeannie Out of the Bottle" by Barbara Eden, the "I Dream of Jeannie" star.

headline.main: Poof! Barbara Eden's 'Jeannie' Memoir Will Appear Next Year

results.snippet: Crown Archetype will release "Jeannie Out of the Bottle" by Barbara Eden, the "I Dream of Jeannie" star.
results.lead_paragraph: For the five seasons that she starred on the classic television comedy "I Dream of Jeannie," Barbara Eden could conjure up anything from valuable artwork to an elephant with a nod and a blink.
